  • joshuajlee
    Jun 04, 2020 5:28 PM

    Does this sound like MS?*



    Hi -

      I'm starting to think that I may have MS.  Curious if my symptoms sound like MS.

      10 years ago at age 36 I rather suddenly had problems starting to pee and the flow was slow.  I couldn't completely empty my bladder either.  I guess from having to push I developed inguinal hernias on both sides a few years after that (7 years ago).

      For two years my job was stressful.  A year and a half ago I started to have more regular ringing in my ears. 

      Last year, after learning my Dad had cancer I become quite stressed.  I first noticed that I would stumble occassionaly when walking. A week or so later I could only walk at a speed a little faster than normal walking.   I could not run.

      My neck became very sore and stiff.  I would feel things crawling on my scalp.  I had an epsiode where my face became numb. My hands were numb.  I could not tell the differece between hot and cold water on my foot.   My blood pressure became higher.  I had difficulty getting to sleep.  I started seeing the ceiling move a couple times.. when this happened I felt a euphoric feeling.  It would last some hours.  My neck became so stiff I could barely move it.  This lasted a couple weeks.  I had difficultly carrying things.  My mother had to carry her own backpack after she flew to see me.  

    Lately I feel mostly OK, but I have a strong ringing in my ears.  My ears feel like they do when they are pressurized.  I've seen an ear, nose & throat specialist & he said my ears look fine inside.  I also feel a little confused sometimes. 

    One more thing.. a couple times I take a hot shower and after my lip or face becomes numb.  

    I had an MRI last year & there are a couple small white matter lesions.  One is maybe 5mm in size.    

    The neurologist said he doesn't think it is MS, because the lesions are not in the periventricular area.  He said white matter lesions are pretty common for someone my age.  I'm 46.

    I live in Hungary.

    Thank you-
    Josh
    0 Appreciate this
  • MS_Navigators
    Jun 05, 2020 11:58 AM


    Hi Josh,

    While none of us here can give you medical guidance or advice, I'd encourage you to reach out to your local MS organization if you have one to find referrals for doctors with MS experience that may possibly provide another opinion.  I hope you get some answers soon.  Here is a list of the MS organizations around the world:

    MSIF- Find Support Near You

    Jessica, MS Navigator
    1 Appreciate this
  • joshuajlee
    Jun 07, 2020 4:32 AM


    I'm curious... what is the most active MS discussion board on the Internet?

    Thank you for that list.  Unfortunately, there is nothing in Hungary.  Maybe I could travel to a nearby country.
    0 Appreciate this
  • maria1
    Jun 06, 2020 10:48 AM


    Hello Josh,  When I get ringing in my ears it is usually from something i have eaten, processed foods have things i cant pronounce so i avoid them until I crave something then I am not surprised to hear the bells. Consider trying to avoid them for a while and see if it makes a difference. Try going for local fresh stuff for a week, switch to water for a while too.

    Not ever ache and pain is ms, if you compare your symptoms to ms and find the ones that dont seem to belong try fixing them, or find the one that bothers you the most and investigate how to fix that one. We always thought my lethargy to be all ms till we learned that I have environmental allergies, now I even do stuff.
    0 Appreciate this
  • joshuajlee
    Jun 07, 2020 4:35 AM


    Thank you for your note Maria.

    Well, I already eat quite healthy.  Very little meat (lately I have been taking b12 too), trying to drink enough water each day.  Taking a few walks every day & not sitting too long.

    I think what I need to do is have another MRI soon to see if there has been any progression with my lesions.  Really, finding out that I have MS would be a relief.  At least I would know what is going on.

    Thank you-
    Josh
    0 Appreciate this
  • maria1
    Jun 07, 2020 8:29 AM


    You did not mention what kind of mri: brain/spine with/without contrast would be good choices, also know that older machines are not as detailed as the newer models. You could consider a lumbar puncture.

    There is on facebook an ms society chat room that is active with newly diagnosed et al. Here there is info posted all the way back to 2012 that has plenty of input about everything. 

    There is a site called multiplesclerosisnewstoday.com which is funded by drug companies so it has plenty of advertising and a lot of articles about what 'might' contribute to ms. dotcom sites are not the same as .org sites like the nmss.org site and here. The nmss.org site also has a link for research where you can take surveys, they helped me focus on what the medical industry considers relevant to ms - to eliminate some worry about symptoms that are not as dramatic as WE think they are, it also got me familiar with medical gargon.

    There are other sites that I am not familiar with, maybe somebody else will post them for you.
    maria
    0 Appreciate this

post_text.surface_form: Hi - I'm starting to think that I may have MS. Curious if my symptoms sound like MS. 10 years ago at age 36 I rather suddenly had problems starting to pee and the flow was slow. I couldn't completely empty my bladder either. I guess from having to push I developed inguinal hernias on both sides a few years after that (7 years ago). For two years my job was stressful. A year and a half ago I started to have more regular ringing in my ears. Last year, after learning my Dad had cancer I become quite stressed. I first noticed that I would stumble occassionaly when walking. A week or so later I could only walk at a speed a little faster than normal walking. I could not run. My neck became very sore and stiff. I would feel things crawling on my scalp. I had an epsiode where my face became numb. My hands were numb. I could not tell the differece between hot and cold water on my foot. My blood pressure became higher. I had difficulty getting to sleep. I started seeing the ceiling move a couple times.. when this happened I felt a euphoric feeling. It would last some hours. My neck became so stiff I could barely move it. This lasted a couple weeks. I had difficultly carrying things. My mother had to carry her own backpack after she flew to see me. Lately I feel mostly OK, but I have a strong ringing in my ears. My ears feel like they do when they are pressurized. I've seen an ear, nose & throat specialist & he said my ears look fine inside. I also feel a little confused sometimes. One more thing.. a couple times I take a hot shower and after my lip or face becomes numb. I had an MRI last year & there are a couple small white matter lesions. One is maybe 5mm in size. The neurologist said he doesn't think it is MS, because the lesions are not in the periventricular area. He said white matter lesions are pretty common for someone my age. I'm 46. I live in Hungary. Thank you- Josh

Hi Josh, While none of us here can give you medical guidance or advice, I'd encourage you to reach out to your local MS organization if you have one to find referrals for doctors with MS experience that may possibly provide another opinion. I hope you get some answers soon. Here is a list of the MS organizations around the world: MSIF- Find Support Near You Jessica, MS Navigator
I'm curious... what is the most active MS discussion board on the Internet? Thank you for that list. Unfortunately, there is nothing in Hungary. Maybe I could travel to a nearby country.

Hello Josh, When I get ringing in my ears it is usually from something i have eaten, processed foods have things i cant pronounce so i avoid them until I crave something then I am not surprised to hear the bells. Consider trying to avoid them for a while and see if it makes a difference. Try going for local fresh stuff for a week, switch to water for a while too. Not ever ache and pain is ms, if you compare your symptoms to ms and find the ones that dont seem to belong try fixing them, or find the one that bothers you the most and investigate how to fix that one. We always thought my lethargy to be all ms till we learned that I have environmental allergies, now I even do stuff.

Thank you for your note Maria. Well, I already eat quite healthy. Very little meat (lately I have been taking b12 too), trying to drink enough water each day. Taking a few walks every day & not sitting too long. I think what I need to do is have another MRI soon to see if there has been any progression with my lesions. Really, finding out that I have MS would be a relief. At least I would know what is going on. Thank you- Josh

You did not mention what kind of mri: brain/spine with/without contrast would be good choices, also know that older machines are not as detailed as the newer models. You could consider a lumbar puncture. There is on facebook an ms society chat room that is active with newly diagnosed et al. Here there is info posted all the way back to 2012 that has plenty of input about everything. There is a site called multiplesclerosisnewstoday.com which is funded by drug companies so it has plenty of advertising and a lot of articles about what 'might' contribute to ms. dotcom sites are not the same as .org sites like the nmss.org site and here. The nmss.org site also has a link for research where you can take surveys, they helped me focus on what the medical industry considers relevant to ms - to eliminate some worry about symptoms that are not as dramatic as WE think they are, it also got me familiar with medical gargon. There are other sites that I am not familiar with, maybe somebody else will post them for you. maria
